issues.title: Some Notes about the usage ov v4 via v6
issues.author: ruben-herold
issues.body:
I found your work in the repository while digging around in Microsoft Windows for IPv4 with IPv6 next hop support and want to share some information with you:

1.  Windows has no support for this, neither static configured nor via windows BGP (I opened tickets and waiting for feedback)
2. There is a EURO-IX working group working to implement it in IX peering LANs: https://github.com/euro-ix/rfc8950-ixp
3.  Also, there is a Test AS to test your systems at major IX's: https://measurement.network/services/v4less-as/
5. frrouting has support for it via bgp, support for adding static routes was merged some days before: https://github.com/FRRouting/frr/pull/18654
6. bird seems to run fine since bird2
7. Mac OSX seems also not to have support for IPv4 with IPv6 next hop.
8. VPP works also since a long time


Also, https://blog.bott.im/bgp-unnumbered-in-2025-same-idea-different-implementations/  could be interested especially https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-white-linklocal-capability-06

pulls.title: ICMP, 192.0.0.8 and RFC1812
pulls.author: furry13
pulls.body:
I found this text a bit confusing:

" every router that is able to forward IPv4 traffic SHOULD be able originate ICMPv4 traffic.  .....a router implementing this extension MUST be able to originate ICMPv4 packets even when the outgoing interface has not been assigned an IPv4 address."

At the very least it seems to contradict RFC1812. 
I'm rewritten that section (which looks like copy-n-paste from RFC9229, citing RFC1812.

Also adding some text why using 192.0.0.8 is not always a great idea.

Last but not least - rephrasing a reference to RFC7404

comments.author: jech
comments.body:
Thanks, Jen.  I'm especially grateful for the bit about the drawbacks of using the dummy address.

If @wkumari and @tokojo agree, I'm going to apply your changes (after squashing them), then do some word-smithing to make your text more stylistically consistent with the rest of the document as hopefully make it more concise.  Please let me know if you disagree with the following changes:

  * rephrase "this document does not contradict RFC 1812" as "RFC 1812 does not specify what happens when there is no router-id assigned";
  * remove the bit about the behaviour being mandated for Babel routers, since RFC 9229 is not normative.

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
>rephrase "this document does not contradict RFC 1812" as "RFC 1812 does not specify what happens when there is no router-id assigned";

LGTM
 
>remove the bit about the behaviour being mandated for Babel routers, since RFC 9229 is not normative.

Actually I removed RFC9229 reference initially, then felt bad about it and put it back, so no objections ;))

pulls.title: Remove implication that NH resolution is per-packet
pulls.author: wkumari
pulls.body:
A few people read:
```the forwarding plane must be able to determine, on a per-packet basis, whether the next-hop address is an IPv4 or an IPv6 address, and to use that information in order to choose the right address resolution protocol to use (ARP for IP4, ND for IPv6).```
as meaning that, *for each packet* the forwarding plane would perform an ARP or ND. 

This is not what we had meant, but I can see how it could be interpreted that way.

comments.author: jech
comments.body:
My mental model is that the forwarding plane makes a call to the ND module for each packet.  Whether the ND module resolves the address by performing a packet exchange or by consulting a cache is an internal implementation detail from which the forwarding plane is isolated.

No idea how to formulate it.

comments.author: wkumari
comments.body:
